message.content:
We can “build” the fixed‐assets net item by starting from the “beginning‐of‐period” balance that is given by the initial “Fixed Assets” row and then adding any purchases representing capital expenditures and subtracting the “Depreciation” charges that are recorded later. (In many problems only fixed–asset acquisitions are posted to the fixed–assets account so that all “Purchase” rows that are for items with product codes like F… or R… are taken as additions to fixed‑assets.)

In our case the transactions include:

1. An initial “Fixed Assets” entry dated 2023‑12‑31 showing an amount of 8,000,000.00. This is our starting (initial) fixed–assets balance.

2. Later on 2023‑12‑31 there are many "Purchase" transactions. In this problem all purchase rows list a product code that begins with an “F” (for F004, F002, F003, F001) or an “R” (for R003, R002, R001) and a product name that (for example) is “Banquet Set”, “Business Meal Set”, “Luxury Suite”, “Quick Meal Set” or “Standard Room”. For the purposes of our calculation we assume that these purchases are fixed–asset acquisitions. Their amounts (taken from the “amount” column) are as follows:

  Purchase20231231001: 371,520.00  
  Purchase20231231002: 829,440.00  
  Purchase20231231003: 35,000.00  
  Purchase20231231004: 1,250,000.00  
  Purchase20231231005: 246,000.00  
  Purchase20231231006: 582,000.00  
  Purchase20231231007: 140,800.00  
  Purchase20231231008: 254,320.00  
  Purchase20231231009: 240,240.00  
  Purchase20231231010: 216,000.00  
  Purchase20231231011: 540,000.00  
  Purchase20231231012: 177,000.00  
  Purchase20231231013: 585,000.00  
  Purchase20231231014: 755,000.00  
  Purchase20231231015: 59,850.00  
  Purchase20231231016: 820,800.00  
  Purchase20231231017: 80,500.00  
  Purchase20231231018: 328,000.00  
  Purchase20231231019: 32,850.00  
  Purchase20231231020: 36,050.00  
  Purchase20231231021: 35,850.00  
  Purchase20231231022: 19,050.00  
  Purchase20231231023: 358,500.00  
  Purchase20231231024: 402,000.00

When we add these amounts together we get: 

  Total fixed–asset purchases =  
    371,520 + 829,440 = 1,200,960  
    + 35,000 = 1,235,960  
    + 1,250,000 = 2,485,960  
    + 246,000 = 2,731,960  
    + 582,000 = 3,313,960  
    + 140,800 = 3,454,760  
    + 254,320 = 3,709,080  
    + 240,240 = 3,949,320  
    + 216,000 = 4,165,320  
    + 540,000 = 4,705,320  
    + 177,000 = 4,882,320  
    + 585,000 = 5,467,320  
    + 755,000 = 6,222,320  
    + 59,850 = 6,282,170  
    + 820,800 = 7,102,970  
    + 80,500 = 7,183,470  
    + 328,000 = 7,511,470  
    + 32,850 = 7,544,320  
    + 36,050 = 7,580,370  
    + 35,850 = 7,616,220  
    + 19,050 = 7,635,270  
    + 358,500 = 7,993,770  
    + 402,000 = 8,395,770.00

3. Next, we subtract the depreciation charges that have been recorded.
There are two depreciation transactions:
  Depreciation20240101001: 45,754.08  
  Depreciation20240201002: 45,755.86  
Their total is: 45,754.08 + 45,755.86 = 91,509.94

Thus we compute:
  Net fixed assets end value = Initial fixed assets + Fixed asset additions – Depreciation  
  = 8,000,000.00 + 8,395,770.00 – 91,509.94  
  = 16,395,770.00 – 91,509.94  
  ≈ 16,304,260.06

So, our answers are:

• Fixed assets net Initial Value: 8,000,000.00  
• Fixed assets net End Value: 16,304,260.06

Below is the answer in the requested json format.

--------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"fixed assets net Initial Value": "8000000.00", "fixed assets net End Value": "16304260.06"} }
```
